name: Methylphenidate
primaryEffects: Increases focus and attention; reduces hyperactivity and impulsivity

interactions.ssri: Generally safe but monitor for serotonin interactions

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for ADHD with extensive clinical evidence

name: Amphetamine Mixed Salts
primaryEffects: Strong increase in focus and energy; reduces ADHD symptoms

interactions.voxra: Increased risk of hypertension and cardiac effects
interactions.ssri: Monitor closely - potential serotonin syndrome risk

evidence.summary: FDA-approved with strong efficacy data for ADHD

name: Lisdexamfetamine
primaryEffects: Smooth and long-lasting focus enhancement; less euphoria than IR amphetamine

evidence.summary: FDA-approved with good safety profile and abuse-deterrent properties

name: Atomoxetine
primaryEffects: Gradual improvement in attention and impulse control; less immediate than stimulants

evidence.summary: FDA-approved non-stimulant ADHD treatment; slower onset

name: Guanfacine
primaryEffects: Improves focus and reduces hyperactivity; calming effect

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for ADHD; particularly helpful for hyperactivity

name: Clonidine
primaryEffects: Reduces hyperactivity and impulsivity; promotes calm

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for ADHD; often used as adjunct

name: Modafinil
primaryEffects: Promotes alertness and reduces fatigue; smoother than traditional stimulants

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for narcolepsy/sleep disorders; strong evidence for wakefulness

name: Armodafinil
primaryEffects: Similar to modafinil but longer-lasting; R-enantiomer only

evidence.summary: FDA-approved; similar profile to modafinil with longer duration

name: Piracetam
primaryEffects: Mild cognitive enhancement; improves verbal fluency and memory
mechanism: Modulates AMPA receptors; improves neuronal membrane fluidity

evidence.summary: Widely studied in Europe; moderate evidence for cognitive benefits

name: Aniracetam
primaryEffects: Enhances verbal fluency and reduces anxiety; fat-soluble racetam

evidence.summary: Limited clinical trials; anecdotal support for cognitive and mood benefits

name: Oxiracetam
primaryEffects: Improves logical thinking and focus; stimulating racetam

evidence.summary: Limited clinical evidence; user reports suggest cognitive benefits

name: Phenylpiracetam
primaryEffects: Stimulating and cognitive enhancing; physical performance boost

evidence.summary: Banned by WADA; limited clinical data but strong anecdotal effects

name: Noopept
primaryEffects: Stronger and faster-acting than piracetam; neuroprotective
mechanism: Increases BDNF and NGF; modulates glutamate

evidence.summary: Limited human trials; popular in nootropic community

name: Alpha-GPC
primaryEffects: Increases acetylcholine; enhances memory and focus

evidence.summary: Evidence for cognitive enhancement and neuroprotection

name: CDP-Choline
primaryEffects: Boosts acetylcholine and dopamine; neuroprotective
mechanism: Provides choline and cytidine for acetylcholine synthesis

evidence.summary: Strong evidence for cognitive enhancement and stroke recovery

name: L-Tyrosine
primaryEffects: Supports dopamine production; improves focus under stress

evidence.summary: Moderate evidence for stress resilience and cognitive performance

name: N-Acetyl L-Tyrosine
primaryEffects: More bioavailable form of L-tyrosine; cognitive support under stress

evidence.summary: Similar to L-tyrosine; debated bioavailability advantage

name: L-Theanine
primaryEffects: Promotes relaxation without sedation; reduces anxiety

evidence.summary: Strong evidence for anxiety reduction and focus enhancement with caffeine

name: Caffeine
primaryEffects: Increases alertness and energy; widely used

evidence.summary: Extensive evidence for alertness and cognitive performance

name: Caffeine + L-Theanine
primaryEffects: Smooth focus and alertness without jitters; synergistic

evidence.summary: Strong synergistic evidence; popular and effective stack

name: Rhodiola Rosea
primaryEffects: Reduces fatigue and stress; enhances endurance
mechanism: Modulates cortisol; supports serotonin and dopamine

evidence.summary: Good evidence for stress reduction and fatigue

name: Ashwagandha
primaryEffects: Reduces stress and anxiety; improves sleep quality

evidence.summary: Strong evidence for stress reduction and anxiety

name: Bacopa Monnieri
primaryEffects: Enhances memory and learning; reduces anxiety

evidence.summary: Good evidence for memory enhancement over time

name: Lion's Mane
primaryEffects: Supports nerve growth and cognitive function; neuroprotective

evidence.summary: Emerging evidence for cognitive support and nerve health

name: Phenibut
primaryEffects: Powerful anxiolytic and euphoric; social enhancer

evidence.summary: Limited clinical use; high abuse and dependence potential

name: Picamilon
primaryEffects: Mild anxiolytic; improves cerebral circulation
mechanism: GABA crosses blood-brain barrier via niacin

evidence.summary: Banned by FDA; limited clinical data

name: Fasoracetam
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety; improves memory and focus

evidence.summary: Very limited clinical data; Phase III trials for ADHD

name: Bromantane
primaryEffects: Increases energy and reduces fatigue without stimulation; anxiolytic
mechanism: Upregulates tyrosine hydroxylase; increases dopamine synthesis

evidence.summary: Used in Russia; limited Western clinical data

name: Semax
primaryEffects: Enhances cognitive function and stress resilience; neuroprotective

evidence.summary: Russian pharmaceutical; limited Western trials

name: Selank
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety without sedation; improves stress resilience

evidence.summary: Russian pharmaceutical; limited Western clinical data

name: Tianeptine Sodium
primaryEffects: Improves mood and reduces anxiety; unique mechanism
mechanism: Atypical action on glutamate and AMPA receptors

evidence.summary: Approved in some countries; unique mechanism

name: Tianeptine Sulfate
primaryEffects: Longer-lasting version of tianeptine sodium; smoother
mechanism: Atypical action on glutamate and AMPA receptors

evidence.summary: Similar to sodium form but extended release

name: Memantine
primaryEffects: Neuroprotective; improves focus and memory at low doses

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for Alzheimer's; off-label cognitive use

name: Agmatine Sulfate
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety and neuropathic pain; mood enhancement

evidence.summary: Limited clinical trials; promising preclinical data

name: Sarcosine
primaryEffects: Enhances cognition and mood; potential antidepressant
mechanism: Glycine transporter-1 inhibitor; increases NMDA activity

evidence.summary: Moderate evidence for cognitive and mood benefits

name: D-Serine
primaryEffects: Cognitive enhancement; potential antipsychotic adjunct

evidence.summary: Clinical evidence in schizophrenia; limited nootropic data

name: Magnesium L-Threonate
primaryEffects: Improves memory and cognitive function; reduces anxiety

evidence.summary: Patented form with evidence for brain magnesium increase

name: Magnesium Glycinate
primaryEffects: Promotes relaxation and sleep; reduces muscle tension

evidence.summary: Well-absorbed form; good for sleep and anxiety

name: Zinc
primaryEffects: Supports cognitive function and mood; immune health

evidence.summary: Essential nutrient; evidence for mood and cognition

name: Vitamin D3
primaryEffects: Supports mood and cognitive function; bone health

evidence.summary: Strong evidence for mood and immune health

name: Omega-3 (EPA/DHA)
primaryEffects: Supports brain health and reduces inflammation; mood benefits

evidence.summary: Extensive evidence for brain health and mood

name: Huperzine A
primaryEffects: Enhances memory and learning; neuroprotective

evidence.summary: Moderate evidence for cognitive enhancement

name: Sulbutiamine
primaryEffects: Increases energy and reduces fatigue; enhances memory
mechanism: Increases thiamine in brain; modulates dopamine

evidence.summary: Limited clinical data; popular in nootropic community

name: Uridine Monophosphate
primaryEffects: Supports dopamine and memory; synergistic with choline and DHA

evidence.summary: Limited clinical evidence; promising preclinical data

name: Creatine Monohydrate
primaryEffects: Enhances cognitive function and physical performance

evidence.summary: Extensive evidence for physical and cognitive benefits

name: Mucuna Pruriens
primaryEffects: Increases dopamine; improves mood and motivation

evidence.summary: Traditional use; limited modern clinical trials

name: Nicotine
primaryEffects: Enhances focus and cognitive performance; highly addictive

evidence.summary: Strong evidence for cognitive enhancement but high addiction risk

name: Pregnenolone
primaryEffects: Enhances memory and reduces fatigue; mood support
mechanism: Precursor to other neurosteroids; NMDA modulation

evidence.summary: Limited clinical evidence; promising mechanism

name: DHEA
primaryEffects: Enhances mood and energy; anti-aging effects

evidence.summary: Moderate evidence for mood and aging

name: Melatonin
primaryEffects: Promotes sleep onset and improves sleep quality

evidence.summary: Strong evidence for sleep and circadian regulation

name: 5-HTP
primaryEffects: Improves mood and sleep; reduces anxiety

evidence.summary: Moderate evidence for mood and sleep

name: Tryptophan
primaryEffects: Promotes sleep and mood; less direct than 5-HTP

evidence.summary: Evidence for sleep and mood support

name: Taurine
primaryEffects: Promotes relaxation and reduces anxiety; cardiovascular support

evidence.summary: Moderate evidence for anxiety and cardiovascular health

name: GABA
primaryEffects: Promotes relaxation; limited brain penetration

evidence.summary: Questionable brain penetration; peripheral effects

name: Kava Kava
primaryEffects: Powerful anxiolytic and muscle relaxant

evidence.summary: Traditional use; hepatotoxicity concerns with poor-quality extracts

name: Valerian Root
primaryEffects: Promotes sleep and reduces anxiety; sedating

evidence.summary: Traditional use; moderate evidence for sleep

name: Lemon Balm
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety and promotes relaxation; cognitive support

evidence.summary: Traditional use; moderate evidence for anxiety

name: Passionflower
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety and improves sleep; sedating

evidence.summary: Traditional use; moderate evidence for anxiety

name: Emoxypine Succinate
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety and oxidative stress; neuroprotective

evidence.summary: Russian pharmaceutical; limited Western data

name: Mirtazapine
primaryEffects: Improves mood and sleep; appetite stimulation

evidence.summary: FDA-approved antidepressant with sedating profile

name: Buspirone
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety without sedation; slow onset

evidence.summary: FDA-approved anxiolytic; non-addictive

name: Hydroxyzine
primaryEffects: Rapid anxiety relief and sedation

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for anxiety; effective PRN option

name: Propranolol
primaryEffects: Reduces physical anxiety symptoms (tremor palpitations)

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for performance anxiety; effective for physical symptoms

name: Pregabalin
primaryEffects: Powerful anxiolytic and pain relief; euphoric at high doses

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for anxiety and neuropathic pain

name: Gabapentin
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety and pain; less potent than pregabalin

evidence.summary: FDA-approved for neuropathic pain; off-label for anxiety

name: Silexan
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety comparable to benzodiazepines; well-tolerated

evidence.summary: Clinical evidence comparable to benzodiazepines without addiction

name: Bupropion
primaryEffects: Improves mood and energy; aids smoking cessation

evidence.summary: FDA-approved antidepressant with activating profile

name: Escitalopram
primaryEffects: Improves mood and reduces anxiety over weeks

evidence.summary: FDA-approved SSRI; first-line for depression and anxiety

name: Temgicoluril
primaryEffects: Reduces anxiety and stress without sedation; Russian pharmaceutical

evidence.summary: Used in Russia; limited Western clinical data

name: Alimemazine
primaryEffects: Strong sedation and anxiety reduction; sleep aid

evidence.summary: Approved in some countries for anxiety and sleep
